 The Catholic priesthood was instituted at the Last Supper. Priests are men who carry out sacrifices. The apostles were the first priests to continue the memorial sacrifice of the Last Supper that paralleled Jesus' sacrifice on the cross. Jesus told them to "do this in memory of me." So this sacrifice must be carried on eternally until Jesus comes again. Jesus is made present in this sacrifice throughout time and space.
 
 The Catholic Church's teaching on why women cannot become priests has to do with the Tradition that Jesus chose 12 men for his apostles and was telling us something by doing this. A more thorough explanation, however, can be found in Pope John Paul II's Theology of the Body. It has to do with the idea that men and women are equal in dignity but not identical in role or attributes. Just as a woman cannot be a husband nor a father, she cannot be a priest. A man cannot be a mother nor a wife (nor a nun).
